citation.article-title: Phylogenetic relationships of filamentous sulfur bacteria (Thiothrix spp. and Eikelboom type 021N bacteria) isolated from wastewater-treatment plants and description of Thiothrix eikelboomii sp. nov., Thiothrix unzii sp. nov., Thiothrix fructosivorans sp. nov. and Thiothrix defluvii sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Thiothrix defluvii sp. nov.
Thiothrix defluvii (de.flu'vi.i. L. neut. n. defluvium sewage; L. gen. n. defluvii of sewage)
Cells are rods, which exist in multicellular filaments.

Base-to-tip differentiation of filaments is observed with basal cells being 2.0-4.0 μm in diameter and 0.5-2.0 μm in length and cells at the tips of filaments being 1.0-2.0 μm in diameter and 5.0-10 μm long.
Cells can be cylindrical or barrel-shaped and elongate swollen cells are often present.
Rosettes, a holdfast and gliding gonidia and knots in filaments may be formed but these are not features of all strains.
Cells deposit intracellular elemental sulfur when grown in the presence of reduced inorganic sulfur compounds.
No volutin granules are present and poly-β-hydroxybutyrate is not deposited.
Growth occurs in the temperature range 10-30°C and there is no growth at 4 or 37°C.
Isolates of this bacterium are extremely slow growing and it has not been possible to determine the biochemical properties of this organism.
The type strain is Thiothrix defluvii Ben57T.
